data.title: will try again
data.text: always overshoot this place, finally tried takeout (3 diff. entrees) and it was solid.  Will try again for sure.

data.title: Nice neighborhood spot
data.text: Good variety of menu items.  Server recommendation couple of appetizers, which were very good.  Dumpling appetizer plenty for 3-4 people.  Service good.  Was crowded, and definitely noisy, but good overall meal

data.title: Dumplings!
data.text: Low key atmosphere, but great dumplings! Not your usual fare by any means. Other dishes are unusual and tasty as well.

data.title: Authentic Chinese food in an unassuming place
data.text: Reading some of the reviews here, it is clear many Americans have not had authentic Chinese cooking, not "Americanzied" as it is in most US restaurants. The unique flavorings of the offerings and their fresh preparation were a complete surprise. The ample choices on the lunch menu are quite the variation, and mostly for $8.50 (!). The cold noodles (appetizer) were not the typical American slop of a cold peanut butter sauce on noodles, but two varieties of noodles in a highly-complex seasoned dish with many layers. (I recommend taking this dish home as take out, as its sauce is a little messy for inhouse eating). For lunch, try the chinese eggplant with basil, a multi-flavor simple recipe and get their house rice with egg for an extra $1 in the lunch menu. If you have only ever tried American Szechaun and want to judge this place by that, don't go. But if a complex, unique kitchen of flavors and an adventure for the taste buds are your game, try this place out. It is clear the change-over of restaurants here is affected how it is viewed. My first impression was tremendous. Portions are ample, so there will be leftovers....

data.title: We liked it
data.text: As previous reviewers have mentioned this has been this site has been the home of at least four Chinese restaurants over the past 40 years.  The Dumpling House is one of the better ones to occupy the place.  The soup dumplings are especially good.  They have a full Chinese menu in addition to the dumplings.  The food was fresh and flavorful.  Service was OK.  Prices are a little high but not outrageous.

data.title: Chinese, not great but expensive
data.text:
This was our second visit and our second evening of flavorless expensive food.  The service lacks as well.  The place, this week, was fairly empty while last week there was a wait.  

With nobody in there, you might expect fairly quick service.  It appeared that only one waitress was working while another stood by and watched, and three other employees stood at the reception desk chatting.  The poor girl was running.  

The best part of the dinner was the Hot and Sour soup; it was tasty.  We ordered three apps. all of which were bland and uninteresting: the cold noodles with chili sauce were absolutely uninteresting; pork and leek dumplings were the best of the three, and; and a scallion pancake which was flavorless and way too thick.  For dinner we ordered, mango shrimp and scallops, Szechuan Beef, and flat noodles with beef.  The flavor of the mango dish wasn't bad except the scallops were clearly not fresh and had a strong fishy taste making them inedible.  The Szechuan beef was not a normal Szechuan beef it was a stew, she mentioned that it was "spicy" but not a stew or soup.  I've ordered Szechuan beef in many Chinese restaurants and while all have a slightly different take, none were a stew.  It's not something you want on a 90-degree day in the summer!  It's something to "mention" to your guests. Finally the "flat noodles with beef" was chow foon, their boring version of chow foon.

Not one of us left feeling good about this restaurant, and we'll likely never go back.

data.title: Delicious authentic menu and dining
data.text: I found the food to be quite tasty, the service excellent, and the venue overall appealing.  Great for families, couples, or singles.  I recommend this for anyone interested in a broad menu with many delicacies.

data.title: Great variety -- amazing tofu!
data.text: They are great on the basics but have exciting alternatives, too, including tofu, dumplings, buns...  Everything is worth a try.  Will withhold msg, although some sauces have it already.  Top rate Newton Chinese/Taiwanese

data.title: Yummy Chinese food
data.text: Be sure to try the mini steamed buns. They are excellent and fun to eat. First, place your dumpling in a soup spoon. Take a bite from the top and suck out the broth. Then add some vinegar and ginger to the dumpling and enjoy. The braised tilapia with tofu in bean sauce was excellent. The whole fish was very well prepared and cooked to perfection. Going back soon to continue exploring the interesting menu.

data.title: The Fourth Time is a Charm
data.text:
Over time, I have seen four Chinese restaurants in this space. Some things don't change -  the hostess in the fourth incarnation was the hostess in the first incarnation - but the food has taken a real turn for the better. 

We have only been once. Two of us ordered soup, two kinds of dumplings and a special with beef, lotus root and other vegetables. The hot and sour soup was very good with plenty of vegetables to go with the tofu. The soup dumplings - not so easy to find in suburban Chinese restaurants - were very good and the standard pot stickers were above average. The stir fried dish was very well cooked - a little too much red pepper for our taste but we could have fixed that if we had thought ahead.

Dumpling house has a very diverse menu (unlike the three previous incarnations). Based on our limited experience, the food is not quite up to the food at Sichuan Gourmet House, several blocks away, but it is still very good and I look forward to eating at Dumpling House again.

data.title: Hugely disappointed
data.text: With all the reviews that hyped this new restaurant, I was let down.  I found the food doughy and starchy.  We had a ton of leftovers and none of us chose to take them home.  I think the owners need to rethink their recipes and make them more healthy.

data.title: Great food for a moderate price
data.text: This restaurant opened a couple of months ago so we thought we would give it a try.  The food was very good and not too expensive. There are about 8 kinds of dumplings and minibuns. We tried 5 and found them to be fresh and quite good. The noodle dishes were authentic but portions were a little on the small side for the price. We did not try much more of the menu as we wanted to try the different dumplings but the place was full of customers. We will certainly go back to try more of the menu.

data.title: I will try again
data.text: Nice and friendly, but I should have told waiter to go away so I could read the menu.  Instead I let him pressure me into ordering something I didn't want.  Oh well.  Dumplings were tasty.  Beef noodle soup billed as spicy was, in my opinion, awful.  Fried rice was delicious but didn't appear to have been fried.

data.title: A nice dumpling place in the 'burbs
data.text:
Great dumplings, and great stir fried noodles. We went on a Tuesday night and it was not too crowded, but I noticed that it does get very full on weekends. Food came in less than 5 minutes after we ordered and is very fresh. The beef noodle soup is meh, but true to its name, the dumplings and xiao long bao (steamed pork buns) are very good. My daughter who declared that "I am not going to eat xiao long bao outside of China" actually ate half of the order. Yes, it is not as good as the ones in Shanghai, or even that in New York Chinatown, but it is probably one of the best we had in Boston.

They also have lunch specials, and some of the items look really good. We will definitely be back to try some of them soon.

data.title: Dumpling delight!
data.text: We had a wonderful lunch at Dumpling House last week.  For sure, their soup dumplings are superb.  The vegetables served in our stir fry where fresh and cooked perfectly.   We tried the lamb teriyaki - which I liked very much.  My friend had the seafood and seaweed soup.  It was a bit on the salty side for both of us, but the flavor was superb.  Definitely looking forward to a return trip.  The service was really very nice - friendly and quick. We saw a number of "regulars" (already) popping in and out for lunch with time to spare to enjoy their eats.

data.title: Meh...
data.text:
I was sorely disappointed with Dumpling House. We ordered the following: 

Scallion Pancake
Spicy Salt and Pepper Wings
Steamed Pork and Leek Dumplings
Hearty Noodle with Pork and Veg

The only thing I would reorder is the Scallion Pancake. It was delicious. Slightly greasy but doughy and crispy. The dipping sauce was very tasty too. 

The wings were ok. Nothing special and definitely not spicy. 

The dumplings were terrible. It tasted like the leeks were pulled from the compost pile. For a dumping house, the number of dumpling types offered (6) is sad. 

The Hearty Noodle was bland. I have never wanted to add salt to my Chinese food before! 

I may return for a snack of scallion pancake but I'll leave the rest of the menu alone.

data.title: Finally a really good restaurant in this location.
data.text: Incredible Wonton Soup, and great Dumplings. House Special Fried Rice was excellent. I am looking forward to trying the Stinky Tofu.

data.title: Hooray! Good local Chinese is back.
data.text: We have been missing Peking Cuisine at 4 Corners since they went out of business years ago. None of the replacements at that location have been worthy of our business. And we'd get Chinese every Sunday night if there were a good local place to go. Hooray for Dumpling House. The food is excellent. The decor is not anything great; I miss Peking Cuisine's tablecloths for dinner and slightly more subdued lighting. But the staff is very friendly and we have enjoyed every dish: dumplings, fish, tofu, and chow fun.

data.title: Solid addition to Chinese food options in Newton
data.text:
First, the bad: We asked if the wonton soup had cilantro and were assured it did not. It came loaded with cilantro. Same with the dumplings whose sauce also had cilantro.

The chicken with broccoli was very tasty and less greasy than a lot of other Chinese places. The wonton soup & dumplings were also good, though my wife couldn't eat them because of the cilantro.

I look forward to trying more dishes at Dumpling House - hope they can work out the ingredient communication glitches.
